elements.title: Al-Asma'i (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the magazine Al-Asma'i (pictured), one of the first publications to emerge in Ottoman Palestine in 1908, was opposed to Zionism and frequently criticized Jewish immigration?

elements.title: One Chun (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that One Chun, a Michelin Guide Bib Gourmand restaurant, has black-and-white televisions, transistor radios, and aged clocks on a wall?

elements.title: Heike Heubach (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Heike Heubach became the first deaf member of the German Bundestag?

elements.title: Carabus japonicus (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that larvae of the species Carabus japonicus prey on earthworms up to 400 times larger than themselves?

elements.title: Jonathan Elliot (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that John Quincy Adams described Jonathan Elliot, his former printer, as "penurious and venal"?

elements.title: Apocalypse Clown (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that an Irish comedy group wrote the film Apocalypse Clown?

elements.title: Anactoria (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that scholars debate whether Anactoria, mentioned in Sappho's poems, was a real person, a pseudonym, or an invention of Sappho?

elements.title: American Colossus (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that American Colossus, a history book that describes how a banker bailed out the U.S. government in 1895, was published around a time when the U.S. government bailed out banks?

elements.title: Joe Gray (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that football player Joe Gray was nicknamed the "Gray Ghost" because when running "it was like he wasn't there anymore"?
